repnme.cdata!:
Mauritius - Financial Sector Supervisory
            Authority Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings show a satisfactory
            outcome, highly likely sustainability, and high
            institutional development impacts. The project offers
            valuable lessons in several areas. First, it demonstrates
            how important financial sector regulation is. Second, it
            underscores the importance of taking a proactive position on
            financial sector policy issues. Third, it illustrates the
            importance of the quality of the policy dialogue, and it
            provides an example of how a state-of-the-art approach to
            financial system regulation could be included in the overall
            policy dialogue between the Bank, and a developing country.
            Fourth, it provides an example of an operational framework
            for a complicated and relatively new subject which the Bank
            and the international community had very little experience
            in, especially for the developing world. Fifth, there are
            also important lessons emerging out of the implementation of
            the project.

5086636.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Mauritius - Financial Sector Supervisory
            Authority Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Sector Supervisory
            Authority Project for Mauritius aims to establish a modern
            well-regulated financial services industry. There are four
            project components. The first assists in developing an
            overall framework for the financial Sector Commission
            (FSC)It also includes advice on the stages of the
            implementation process, including staff needs and structural
            issues. The second component finances the review of existing
            standards, policies, and procedures; the development of
            standards for market conduct and prudential regulations; the
            development of internal policies and procedures concerning
            risk management; and the review of long-range goals. The
            third component funds staff training and skills building.
            The fourth component assesses the information technlogy
            needs of the FSC, including any equipment that it may
            inherit from the existing agencies; and procures and
            installs suitable equipment.
